hw_name.description: This is the VESC Logging and Communication Module.

tune.pid.kp.description:
Angle P (Proportional)

Determines how strong the board responds to a difference in Board Angle vs. Setpoint Angle (i.e. nose below setpoint will accelerate, nose above setpoint will brake).


Recommended Values: 10 - 35 (Take caution closer to 35!)


*Note: Angle P and Rate P work together to shape a large part of the ride feel. If trying to soften the effects of both and you would like to maintain the ride feel, these values should be adjusted together by the same proportion (i.e. If reducing Angle P by half, such as from 20 -> 10, Rate P should be reduced by half as well, such as from 0.6 -> 0.3).

tune.pid.kd.description:
Rate P (Proportional) value

Determines how strong the board responds to the nose's angular velocity, regardless of setpoint (i.e. pushing nose down will accelerate, pulling nose up will brake).

Most noticeable in quick/aggressive manuevers, as well as scenarios where Angle P is not effective. For example, coming from hard braking (nose high above setpoint), Rate P will allow the board to begin to accelerate the moment you start pushing the nose down, before the nose is even below setpoint.


For our use case, while Rate P is a Proportional value, we utilize it practically as the D (Derivative) component for our PID loop, working as a damper for the Angle P component.


Recommended Values: 0.1 - 0.8

(0.7 - 1.2+ is possible, may experience negative side effects)


*Note: Angle P and Rate P work together to shape a large part of the ride feel. If trying to soften the effects of both and you would like to maintain the ride feel, these values should be adjusted together by the same proportion (i.e. If reducing Angle P by half, such as from 20 -> 10, Rate P should be reduced by half as well, such as from 0.6 -> 0.3).

tune.pid.kd_filter.description: Half time of D Term filtering, which creates an interesting spongy feeling. Some specific values can induce vibrations.

tune.pid.ki.description:
Angle I (Integral) value

As time passes with the board angle away from setpoint (considered "error"), Angle I will strengthen the board response based on cumulative error over time. Can be a subtle effect, and has most noticeable effect at the start of uphills/downhills, as well as tricks involving motor freespin.


Recommended Values: 0 - 20 (Caution with higher values!)

tune.pid.ki_limit.description:
I Term Limiter (Limit Integral Amps)

Limits the amount of current the I component of PID is allowed to accumulate over time. This limits the max response in scenarios with extreme error, such as inclines/declines, as well as freespin tricks, curb nudges, etc. that may overshoot on the landing otherwise.


Recommended Value: 20A - 30A


*Note: 0 = Disabled (Not Recommended)


*Note: Was under the parameter "Deadzone" in previous firmware versions. The values used for that parameter before are now scaled up 10x (i.e. a previous "Deadzone" value of 3, is now an I Term Limit of 30A).

tune.pid.kp_brake.description:
Scales your Angle P value for braking. For example, if:

Angle P = 20,

Angle P (Braking) = 0.5x,

then your brakes will use an Angle P of 10, half the strength of your acceleration Angle P.

tune.pid.kd_brake.description:
Scales your Rate P value for braking. For example, if:

Rate P = 0.6,

Rate P (Braking) = 0.5x,

then your brakes will use a Rate P of 0.3, half the strength of your acceleration Rate P.

tune.traction.wheelslip_strength.description: PID output will get multiplied by this number when wheelslip is detected. WARNING - careful when close to 0.

tune.traction.wheelslip_threshold.description: TODO write description dude.

tune.traction.drop_strength.description: PID output will get multiplied by this number when free fall is detected. WARNING - if set close to 0, the board can become soft on steep descends!

tune.traction.drop_threshold.description: For drop detection, we want to isolate free fall only (or even pushing the board down while dropping). This let's you specify the free fall range. WARNING - do not set this too close to 1, otherwise normal riding will be affected!

tune.traction.filter.description: Half time of wheelslip and drop detection filtering. Lower values will be more responsive but twitchy, higher values should get rid of false positives at the cost of being mushier. Do not go all the way to 0.

tune.traction.soft_release_winddown.description: Essentially how long will modifiers winddown after a loss of traction was detected.

tune.traction.mod_winddown.description: Essentially how quickly will modifiers winddown after a loss of traction was detected.

tune.balance_filter.mahony_kp.description:
KP for the pitch axis of the Mahony IMU Filter

Defines the amount of accelerometer correction applied to the pitch axis (forward-backward tilt) of the Mahony filter.


In practice, increasing this value will loosen up the board, specifically in the center of the board and in how quickly it rebounds to level. If you want a snappier board, drop this down a bit. If you want things a bit looser, with increased board angle control, bump it up a notch or two.


This parameter is amongst those that have the most impact on the feel of the ride and how the board behaves in ondulated terrain.


Recommended Values: 1.5 - 2.5 (Caution with higher values!)

tune.balance_filter.mahony_kp_roll.description:
KP for the roll axis of the Mahony IMU Filter

Defines the amount of accelerometer correction applied to the roll axis (board sideways rotation) of the Mahony filter.


High Pitch KP makes the board response mellow and makes the tilt "linger" longer. This is not desireable for the roll axis, because as the board rotates in yaw during a turn, roll becomes pitch. If you roll a board to the side when making a turn, the angle will propagate into your pitch and the nose will be dipping when turning. This effect is presumably more pronounced with rounder tires.


Setting the Roll KP lower than Pitch KP will make the nose hold up better in turns and make the board stiffer in general, and especially in tight carves.


However, unequal axes KPs skew the Mahony's mathematical model and setting Roll KP too low brings unwanted side-effects, like the board being twitchy and the nose lifting too much during sudden rotations.


Recommended Values: 0.8 - 1.8

tune.balance_filter.accel_confidence_dec.description: Sets how fast the accelerometer confidence will be decreased if the acceleration vector differs from 1.0.

tune.balance_filter.az_filter.description: Half time of Accel Z filtering. Normally this is done in App Cfg, but here it's moved into the package to allow reading raw acceleration. So make sure to leave accelerometer filtering at 0 Hz in App Cfg if you want drop detection to work well.

hardware.esc.frequency.description:
Frequency of Balance Loop Cycle


Recommended Value: Same or multiple of IMU Sample Rate

  • Little FOCer v3.1 (LSM6DS3): 832Hz
  • Little FOCer v3 (BMI160): 800Hz

hardware.esc.imu_x_offset.description: Distance from the axle to the controller in meters. Usually around 0.2 m. This helps get a more precise accelerometer measurement used for Drop Detection. Tested on ADV, not sure if other controllers/orientations will work. If unsure, leave it at 0.

faults.pitch_threshold.description: Pitch Angle at which a fault is triggered and the board is disengaged. Can help potentially cut-off a runaway board with a stuck sensor (a.k.a "Ghosting").

faults.roll_threshold.description: Roll Angle at which a fault is triggered and the board is disengaged. Can help potentially cut-off a runaway board with a stuck sensor (a.k.a "Ghosting").

faults.adc1_threshold.description:
Voltage below this value will trigger a fault for the corresponding sensor zone. To disable this switch, set this value to 0.


Hint: If voltage with no input does not settle near 0, consider a pulldown resisitor!

faults.adc2_threshold.description:
Voltage below this value will trigger a fault for the corresponding sensor zone. To disable this switch, set this value to 0.


Hint: If voltage with no input does not settle near 0, consider a pulldown resisitor!

faults.pitch_delay.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Pitch Axis Fault is detected.

faults.roll_delay.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Roll Axis Fault is detected.

faults.switch_half_delay.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Half Switch Fault is detected.

faults.switch_full_delay.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Full Switch Fault is detected.

faults.switch_half_speed.description:
ERPM (absoulte value) below which a Half State on the ADC switches (sensor zones) will be considered a Fault.


*Note: ERPM = RPM * (Motor Poles / 2)
For an 11" Tire on a Hypercore Motor (30 Poles):
1000 ERPM ≈ 2.2 mph ≈ 3.5 km/h

faults.is_posi_enabled.description:
Treats both sensors as one single-zone sensor (a.k.a. Posi Sensor). Can help guarantee continued sensor engagement, especially at low speed, but disables the Half Switch Fault (Heel Lift dismount) and can present extra ghosting risk if a sensor is stuck.


*Note: For Advanced Riders only!

faults.moving_fault_disabled.description:
Disables ADC Faults completely as long as ERPM is positive (moving forward) and above the Half State Fault ERPM x2, as well as the Roll angle being within 40° of level. Outside of the threshold, the board will not disengage on its own, but rather just default to allowing ADC Faults to disengage the board.


*DISCLAIMER: Requires correct speed calibration and Tail Heavy Board!! The board WILL ghost for sure if your normal speeds read as negative or if your board is nose heavy!!

faults.is_reversestop_enabled.description:
Allows stopping the onewheel gently by going backwards a bit. Will slowly tilt until it exceeds 15 degrees, and then turn off. It will also stop if going in reverse and staying above 5 degrees tilt for 1+ seconds, or above 10 degrees tilt for 0.5+ seconds.


*Note: With Reverse Stop enabled, it's much harder if not impossible to balance standing still


*DISCLAIMER: Requires correct speed calibration!! You WON'T be able to go forward if your normal speeds are negative!!

faults.ghost_delay.description: For how long does the board have to travel backwards (faster than the threshold) before disengaging. Lower value will catch ghosts sooner, but you will have less time to react when there is a false positive (riding backwards fast with only one sensor active).

faults.ghost_speed.description: How fast does the board have to travel backwards before before the timer starts. Lower value will catch ghosts sooner, but it will trigger easier when just rocking back and forth.

haptics.strength.description: Strength/loudness of haptic feedback.

haptics.strength_at_speed.description: Strength/loudness of haptic feedback at high speeds.

haptics.frequency.description: Frequency of the produced Haptic Buzz beeps. Lower values will be felt, higher values heard. Maximum frequency is limited by the update frequency of this package (Specs - Loop Frequency). It is recommended to not go above quarter of that.

haptics.speed.description: Frequency of the actual beeps. 5 Hz means 5 beeps per second.

warnings.duty_threshold.description:
Duty Cycle threshold to trigger a safety pushback (Pushback raises the nose of the board, informing you to slow down).


*Note: Can be disabled by setting to 100%


*DISCLAIMER: Max Duty Cycle on a VESC is 95%, NOT 100%! Reaching 95% Duty Cycle and pushing beyond WILL result in a nosedive. Use this knowledge to leave yourself the headroom you desire.

warnings.lv_threshold.description: When to start Low Voltage warning. This is per cell, so generally doesn't need to be changed (instead configure number of cells) and should be around 3.0 V. Please respect this warning, stop riding and chanrge the board.

warnings.hv_threshold.description: When to start High Voltage warning. This is per cell, so generally doesn't need to be changed (instead configure number of cells) and should be around 4.3 V. Please respect this warning, perhaps ride around for a few minutes before going down a hill with a full battery.

warnings.tiltback_return_speed.description: Speed at which nose is returned back to normal after a pushback condition has been cleared.

tune.speed_tilt.constant.description:
Tiltback that will be applied above a configurable minimum ERPM. AKA Nose Angle adjustment, can be downwards (negative) too.


*Note: Should not be used to accomodate tilted rail angle! Instead, the IMU calibration should be adjusted accordingly, either manually or using the IMU Wizard. Otherwise, you will experience the opposite of the desired effect while riding backwards.

tune.speed_tilt.variable.description:
Nose Angle adjustment that will be applied depending on speed, specified in degrees per 1000 ERPM, applied linearly as the rate at which you approach Variable Tiltback Maximum. Applies in addition to Constant Tiltback.

*Note: ERPM = RPM * (Motor Poles / 2)
For an 11" Tire on a Hypercore Motor (30 Poles):
1000 ERPM ≈ 2.2 mph ≈ 3.5 km/h

hardware.remote.type.description:
Select how the remote's reciever communicates with VESC (PPM or UART).


Note: Remote Tiltback requires an input device (such as a UART/PPM Eskate remote)! If not applicable, the type should remain as "None."


Note: For PPM, make sure to keep the Beeper DISABLED (under "Specs" tab) for proper functionality. A reboot may be required following the switch.

hardware.remote.invert_throttle.description:
False:

  • Throttle Forward = Nose Lift
  • Throttle Backward = Nose Lower


True (Default):

  • Throttle Forward = Nose Lower
  • Throttle Backward = Nose Lift

tune.input_tilt.angle_limit.description:
Maximum angle to which Remote Tiltback will tilt. Determines the scaling of throttle-to-angle (i.e. Max Angle of 10° + 50% Throttle = 5° Tilt Angle).


Note: Pitch Axis Faults and Quickstop will be disabled when Remote Tilt Setpoint is beyond 30°, making it safe to use for Vert.


WARNING: Tilting the setpoint beyond the point of nose/tail dragging will cause the board to accelerate on its own (tail dragging forward). Additionally, a high maximum tilt angle can result in unintended nose/tail diving at speed when not used carefully. BE CAUTIOUS when using maximum angles beyond 20°!

tune.input_tilt.speed_limit.description: Rate at which Remote Tiltback will tilt to the desired angle.

tune.input_tilt.filter.description: Half time of throttle filtering.

tune.input_tilt.threshold.description:
Deadband region for the center of the input throttle. Can assist with remotes that do not fully return to center.


For example, a Deadband of 10% will only begin adjusting setpoint once the throttle reaches a value of +/- 10%. From there, it will scale as if 10% throttle was the center point (0%).

startup.pitch_tolerance.description: Pitch Angle range from "Level" at which the board is allowed to engage. Measured in degrees from Level (0° Pitch).

startup.roll_tolerance.description: Roll Angle (Heel-to-Toe) range from "Flat" at which the board is allowed to engage. Measured in degrees from Flat (0° Roll).

startup.speed.description: Rate at which the board will level itself on startup.

startup.simplestart_enabled.description: Allow starting with a single sensor, while still allowing heel-lift dismounts. To avoid accidental re-engagement when heel-lift dismounting, this feature is disabled for a few seconds from the last disengagement.

startup.pushstart_enabled.description: Allow starting the board by jumping onto it, regardless of pitch angle, as long as the speed is 1000 ERPM (~2 mph) or higher.

startup.dirtylandings_enabled.description: Allow landing with an extra 10 degrees pitch tilt within 1 second of disengaging both sensors (not active after heel-lift dismount).

tune.pid.soft_start.description: How long does it take for PID to take full effect. This removes the distinct click.

brake_current.description: Brake current to be applied when board is not actively engaged (only applied when an outside force causes motor to move).

tune.modifiers.speed_limit.description: Maximum speed at which modifiers will tilt to the desired angle.

tune.modifiers.filter.description: Half time of modifier filtering. This is applied after the final targets are calculated. Stronger filter will make modifiers smoother but slower.

tune.modifiers.board_speed_filter.description: Board speed fuses accelerometer and ERPM, this value influences how long it takes to approach the noisier (but on average correct) ERPM value.

tune.modifiers.acceleration_source.description: Used for ATR and Torque Tilt. IMU will be smoother but will not adapt to road slope properly.

tune.modifiers.use_erpm_correction.description: Subtract speed caused by pitch changes.

tune.torque_tilt.enabled.description: Master switch for debugging purposes.

tune.torque_tilt.strength.description:
How much Nose Lift should be applied based on output current (Postive / Acceleration Current Only!). Can be used alongside ATR to increase aggressiveness on flat and uphill acceleration, or on its own to ensure some uphill tiltback is applied in the absence of ATR.


Recommended Values: 0 - 0.35

tune.torque_tilt.strength_regen.description:
How much Nose Lowering should be applied based on output current (Negative / Regen Current Only!). Can be used alongside ATR to increase aggressiveness on flat and downhill braking, or on its own to ensure some downhill nose lowering is applied in the absence of ATR.


Recommended Values: 0 - 0.35

tune.torque_tilt.strength_boost.description: Torque Tilt strength multiplier at 10K ERPM. Applied exponentially.

tune.torque_tilt.threshold.description: Minimum output torque threshold for Torque Tiltback to start applying.

tune.torque_tilt.angle_limit.description: Maximum angle to which Torque Tiltback will tilt.

tune.torque_tilt.method.description: EXPERIMENTAL: 0.0 is the classic Amp based Torque Tilt, 1.0 incorporates measured ERPM acceleration as well. That way it doesn't interfere with setpoint when simply maintaining speed.

tune.torque_tilt.filter.description: Half time of current/accel complementary filtering. 0 is purely acceleration based, higher values will smooth out its influence (while still using high frequency information of current), which should make wheel locks and slashes more predictable, but will introduce more delay.

tune.torque_tilt.turn_boost.description: Intensifies Torque Tilt based on Yaw Rate. Similar effect to Turn Tilt, but reversed for regen - that way the corner that's closest to the ground gets lifted.

tune.atr.enabled.description: Master switch for debugging purposes.

tune.atr.strength_up.description: 1 should be parallel to the ground, 0 is disabled.

tune.atr.strength_down.description: 1 should be parallel to the ground, 0 is disabled.

tune.atr.strength_boost.description: ATR strength multiplier at 10K ERPM. Applied exponentially.

tune.atr.tightness.description: EXPERIMENTAL. Reduces Mahony KP.

tune.atr.threshold.description:
Threshold angle for acceleration/uphills below which no setpoint change is triggered. This means that if the computed ATR angle is below this threshold the setpoint will not be changed, producing a more predictable behavior in mellow terrain.


Once the ATR target angle exceeds the threshold, setpoint changes will be produced.


Example: If the threshold is 2 and the computed ATR angle is 3 then a 1 degree setpoint adjustment will be performed.

tune.atr.angle_limit.description: Maximum angle to which ATR is permitted to tilt.

tune.turn_tilt.strength.description: How much Tiltback should be applied based on turning radius (Yaw) and speed.

tune.turn_tilt.strength_boost.description: Turn Tilt strength multiplier at 10 m/s. Applied exponentially.

tune.turn_tilt.angle_limit.description: Maximum angle to which Turn Tiltback will tilt. This wont change the power curve, only stop it at the limit.

tune.turn_tilt.start_erpm.description:
ERPM threshold to apply Turn Tiltback.


*Note: ERPM = RPM * (Motor Poles / 2)
For an 11" Tire on a Hypercore Motor (30 Poles):
1000 ERPM ≈ 2.2 mph ≈ 3.5 km/h

tune.turn_tilt.filter.description: Half time of yaw rate filtering.

leds.on.description: Turns LEDs on or off completely.

leds.headlights_on.description:
Turns headlights and tail lights on or off. Headlights and taillights activate when you engage the board (using the Headlights Transition). They switch according to the direction you ride.


Primary use of headlights is the white and red light for riding at night, but the settings are the exact same for Headlights, Taillights, Front and Rear. Use headlights to get whatever cool effect you want that'll switch to nose/tail according to the direction you ride.

leds.headlights_transition.description: Transition to and from headlights and taillights. Occurs when you engage the board if you have the headlights on.

leds.direction_transition.description: Transition used when you change ride direction to switch from headlights to taillights on the front and back LED strips. Not used if you have headlights off.

leds.lights_off_when_lifted.description: When enabled, turns off front and rear leds when you lift the board nose up (pitch angle > 60°). So that the LEDs don't blast into your eyes when you carry it.

leds.status_on_front_when_lifted.description:
Show the status bar on the front LED strip when you lift the board nose up (pitch angle > 60°).


If you have Lights Off When Lifted on at the same time, will go dark after 3 seconds. You can make it show again by pressing the footpad sensor.

leds.front.mode.description: Front LED strip mode (effect) when headlights are off.

leds.front.brightness.description:
Front LED strip brightness when headlights are off.


Note: On very low brightness levels the LEDs will lose color precision and eventually turn off completely. This is a limitation of the LED strips and can't be alleviated.

leds.front.color1.description:
Front primary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.front.color2.description:
Front secondary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.front.speed.description: Front animation speed.

leds.rear.mode.description: Rear LED strip mode (effect) when headlights are off.

leds.rear.brightness.description:
Rear LED strip brightness when headlights are off.


Note: On very low brightness levels the LEDs will lose color precision and eventually turn off completely. This is a limitation of the LED strips and can't be alleviated.

leds.rear.color1.description:
Rear primary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.rear.color2.description:
Rear secondary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.rear.speed.description: Rear animation speed.

leds.headlights.mode.description: Forward-facing strip (switches according to ride direction) mode (effect) when headlights are on.

leds.headlights.brightness.description:
Forward-facing strip (switches according to ride direction) brightness when headlights are on.


Note: Default is conservatively set to 50%. Set to 100% to get the maximum headlights brightness.


Note: On very low brightness levels the LEDs will lose color precision and eventually turn off completely. This is a limitation of the LED strips and can't be alleviated.

leds.headlights.color1.description:
Headlights primary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.headlights.color2.description:
Headlights secondary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.headlights.speed.description: Headlights animation speed.

leds.taillights.mode.description: Backwards-facing strip (switches according to ride direction) mode (effect) when headlights are on.

leds.taillights.brightness.description:
Backwards-facing strip (switches according to ride direction) brightness when headlights are on.


Note: On very low brightness levels the LEDs will lose color precision and eventually turn off completely. This is a limitation of the LED strips and can't be alleviated.

leds.taillights.color1.description:
Taillights primary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.taillights.color2.description:
Taillights secondary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.taillights.speed.description: Taillights animation speed.

leds.status.brightness_headlights_off.description:
Status brightness when headlights are off, intended to be daylight-level brightness. Set high so that you can see the status in direct sunlight.


Note: On very low brightness levels the LEDs will lose color precision and eventually turn off completely. This is a limitation of the LED strips and can't be alleviated.

leds.status.brightness_headlights_on.description:
Status brightness when headlights are on, intended to be night-time brightness. Set low so that the status bar doesn't glare into your eyes when it's dark.


Note: On very low brightness levels the LEDs will lose color precision and eventually turn off completely. This is a limitation of the LED strips and can't be alleviated.

leds.status.show_sensors_while_running.description: When on, the blue footpad sensor indicators will show while running, if at least one of the sensors is deactivated. When off, no footpad sensor indicators will be shown.

leds.status.duty_threshold.description:
Duty threshold at which the duty is shown on the status bar instead of the battery. Note there is a 10% hysteresis, meaning if you duty shows at 20%, it will be shown until it drops below 10% (to avoid constant blinking). Values below 15% set the threshold to 15%.


Set to 0 to not show the duty bar.


Note: Since duty above 95% is not achievable and you're unlikely to ever benefit from values above 90% being shown on your status bar, duty level of 90% is scaled to 100% on the status bar to make full use of its real estate.

leds.status.red_bar_percentage.description: Percent threshold at which the low end of the battery bar and the hight end of the duty bar will be colored red. Mainly inteded to fine-tune the amount of red LEDs on status bars with different LED counts.

leds.status.idle_timeout.description:
Amount of seconds after which the status bar hoes into Idle. In Idle the status bar shows an animation which can be configured just like the Front / Rear animations.


Set to 0 to disable Idle.

leds.status_idle.mode.description: Status Idle mode (effect). Set Status Idle Timeout to a non-zero value to enable the Status Idle mode.

leds.status_idle.brightness.description:
Status brightness when in Idle.


Note: On very low brightness levels the LEDs will lose color precision and eventually turn off completely. This is a limitation of the LED strips and can't be alleviated.

leds.status_idle.color1.description:
Status Idle primary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.status_idle.color2.description:
Satus Idle secondary color.


Note: There are three whites due to the extra white channel on RGBW LEDs:

  • White (full) is full brightness on all four channels, the brightest it can be. It also consumes the most power. On RGB LEDs, this is the same as White (rgb).
  • White (rgb) is the white of the three RGB channels.
  • White (single) only works on RGBW and is the single white channel. It's black on RGB-only LEDs. Less bright than White (full), but consumes significantly less power.

leds.status_idle.speed.description: Status Idle animation speed.

hardware.leds.type.description:
LED Strip Type


  • None: Disable LED controls
  • RGB: 3 channel LEDs (WS2811, WS2812b, etc.)
  • RGBW: 4 channel LEDs with white channel (WS2815, SK2812, SK6812, etc.)
  • External Module: External LED control modules, such as the Floatwheel LCM


External Module (LCM)

External Modules have their own simple LED configuration, which uses three brightness levels:

  • Brightness
  • Brightness (Idle)
  • Status Brightness


For configuring these from Stig, the following Stig options will be used for the above LCM parameters respectively (for status, the one used depends on the Headlights On switch):

  • Headlights Brightness
  • Front Brightness
  • Status Brightness (Headlights Off)
  • Status Brightness (Headlights On)


You can use the LEDs On switch to turn LCM lights on and off.


You can toggle the Headlights On switch to have Headlights Brightness be used when engaged. When it's off, Front Brightness will be used regardless of whether the board is engaged or idle. Also, the corresponding Status Brightness will be used.


The rest of the options is ignored for the External Module LED type.


Board restart required for changes to take effect.


Note: Pressing both footpad sensors when turning on the board will disable the LED initialization. Use if the LEDs break your VESC in a way that prevents you to connect and change configuration (e.g. due to an overcurrent).

hardware.leds.pin.description:
The pin to which the LEDs are connected on the VESC.


  • PPM/Servo pin: Little FOCer v3.x, Tronic 250R, Ubox V2 75V/100V (pin B6)
  • Dedicated LED pin: Little FOCer v4.x, Thor 300 (pin B7)


Board restart required for changes to take effect.


Note: For the PPM/Servo pin to work, you need to remove a capacitor from the VESC. For Little FOCer / Tronic it's the C3 capacitor.

hardware.leds.status.count.description:
Number of LEDs in your status bar strip. The status bar strip must be the first in the chain of LEDs. If you dont have a status bar, set this to 0.


Board restart required for changes to take effect.

hardware.leds.status.reverse.description:
Reverse the direction of the status bar LED strip.


Board restart required for changes to take effect.

hardware.leds.front.count.description:
The number of LEDs in your front LED strip. This strip must be the 2nd in your chain of LEDs, wired after the status LEDs and before the rear LEDs. Set to 0 if you don't have a front LED strip.


Board restart required for changes to take effect.

hardware.leds.front.reverse.description:
Reverse the direction of the front LED strip.


Board restart required for changes to take effect.

hardware.leds.rear.count.description:
The number of LEDs in your rear LED strip. This strip must be the 3rd in your chain of LEDs, wired after the status LEDs and front LEDs. Set to 0 if you don't have a rear LED strip.


Board restart required for changes to take effect.

hardware.leds.rear.reverse.description:
Reverse the direction of the rear LED strip.


Board restart required for changes to take effect.

hardware.mass.description: Mass of the board in kilograms, used for slope estimation.

hardware.motor.torque_constant.description: In electric motors, torque is proportional to current. This constant specifies how much torque [Nm] does one unit of current [A] produce. The goal of this is to unify tunes for different motors. Used by ATR and Torque Tilt. Can be calculated from flux linkage and motor poles as 1.5 * lambda * pole_pairs. Expected values: 0.5-0.9.

hardware.motor.rolling_resistance.description: It takes some force to start rolling. Softer tire/terrain might require higher Cr. For ATR, this acts as "torque offset" at low speeds. Expected values: 0.02-0.08.

hardware.motor.acceleration_resistance.description: There are additional resistances present when accelerating, for example rotational inertia increasing the effective mass. In theory, this should be slightly above 1. Expected values: 0.7-1.4.

hardware.esc.is_beeper_enabled.description: Enable/disable beeper. Beeper is controlled by Servo/PPM. Active beeper required, 3pin version recommended.

rider.mass.description: Mass of the rider (geared) in kilograms, used for torque and slope estimation.

rider.drag_coefficient.description: Used for drag calculation. For ATR, this acts as "torque offset" at high speeds. Expected values: 1.0-1.5.

disabled.description:
For Initial Setup Only!

Use this option when you need to run the motor wizard or you want to troubleshoot your motor and run terminal commands. Riding won't be possible with this set to true.
